RIFLE TEAM DEFEATS YALE
As this issue was going to
press the final results of the Intercollegiate Rifle Match were received. Hopkins nosed out Yale
in the last few rounds, finishing
46 points ahead of the New Haven
marksmen. The Black and Blue
team was 14th on the list, the
match being won by Penn., with
Norwich and Oregon a close second and third.
Among the other teams defeated by the Hopkins riflemen were
Columbia, California, Princeton,
Dartmouth, Boston Tech., LelandStanford, West Virginia and University of Maine.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 25, 1922

THE R. 0. T. C. INSPECTION
The Reserve Officers' Training Corps Unit of this University
is one of which the students have every right to feel proud. Since its
organization at Hopkins the unit has ever maintained a high standard
and has established a most enviable record.
Under the leadership of Major Enoch B. Garey the corps has
grown in leaps and bounds, both in strength and in popularity. Due
to the efforts of this progressive officer and the members of his staff,
the organization has greatly expanded and is now fully equipped
to give a thorough schooling in the military.

At Virginia it soon became apparent that Dr. Rogers would
achieve fame in the world of Political Science. It was, .therefore,
not so much of a surprise when he
received the appointment of associate professor of Political Science
at Columbia University, even
though he was unusually young to
hold such a position. At the same
time he accepted his appointment to
Columbia. Dr. Rogers refused a
bid to the chair of associate professor of Political Science at Harvard. At present, although Dr.
Rogers is only thirty-one years of
age, his name has been placed upon
the list of "Who's Who in America."
Dr. Rogers is also delivering one
of the series of Albert Shaw lectures.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 25, 1922
TENNIS TEAM TO MEET LOYOLA

On Wednesday, April 26, the
tennis team, under the leadership
of Captain Duffy, will meet the
Loyola racqueters on the Homewood courts. The visitors have just
returned from a trip through Virginia, where they faced some of the
strongest country club teams in the
state. They have also tackled a
number of college teams and have
made a very creditable showing.
The team will be made up of
Kerr
and
Barrett,
Menton,
Sweeney, who for several years
held the Junior State Championship and played on the Baltimore
Country Club tennis team last season. They will be met by a team
picked from the following list of
Hopkins men: Rowland, Wells,
Hofmeister, Bloom. Jacobsen and
Duffy.
On April 29 Hopkins will meet
Drexel, and on the third of May
Catholic University will come here
for a match, followed by one with
Gettysburg, on the fifth,- A return
match will be staged at "Evergreen" on May 17 with Loyola.
The tournament has .been progressing slowly, owing to the intervention of the holidays. Captain
Duffy urges all the participants to
Play off their first two rounds by
the end of next week.
It is with great pleasure that the
followers of the tennis ball observe
the improvements which are being
made on the courts. Wire netting
has been placed on the backstops
and the steam roller has done much
to put the courts in good condition.

SOCIETY

Mr. E. Ault, a member of the
class of 1920, now engaged in graduate engineering work at Cornell
University, delivered an address
on "The Graduate in the Engineering Field," at the last meeting of
the Hopkins branch of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
Mr. Ault stated that there are
a number of things that the young
mechanical engineer must consider
before taking a job. First, be must
determine if he has adequate training to do the necessary work. Then,
he must take note of how much
experience and knowledge he will
gain. This is, perhaps, the most
important consideration. "Indeed,
some engineers," he said, "change
jobs every three months for the
first five or six years after leaving
college, in order to gain practical
experience."
Another thing to decide, according to Mr. Ault, is whether one desires to stay at home or whether
one is willing to travel. Of course,
everyone likes to stay at home with
his friends and family. There are
a number of disadvantages, however, in staying at home, for in this
case one must accept whatever po-

Those who have given their lives and their
hearts to the service of the electrical art have
early learned that success with larger things is
assembled out of devoted care to the lesser details. Indeed, they will go further, and demonstrate that the little achievements of today are
the fundamentals that become the big things of
tomorrow. Just as Willie Hoppe, the great
billiardist, will tell you that there is no such
thing as an easy shot in billiards, so electrical
specialists have found that frequently the seemingly big conceptions have depended on the perfection of details that those unfamiliar with
electrical history would often mistakenly regard
as unimportant.
Thus the growth of Westinghouse, and of the
great industry of which it is a part, has been
compounded of many ingredients; of vision that
saw present needs and future requirements, of
engineering genius that could bring forth practicable designs to fill them, of courage that never
failed to try once more, of enthusiasm, and integrity, and faithfulness to the little and the
little-known jobs as well as to those that were
bigger and more pretentious. Westinghouse has
always had a need, and a welcome, for men who
could supply such qualities.

It is the daily expression of qualities like these
that earns a man the regard, as well as the respect, of those who work with him.
Perhaps the foregoing may suggest some of the
causes that lie behind the success, and this appreciation, of Harry Phillips Davis, Vice President in executive charge of all Westinghouse
production and engineering activities. During
the thirty-odd years of his service he has contributed consistently to electrical progress, not
only by his work on arc lights and meters and
transmission apparatus, but by his effective and
loyal attention to the detailed requirements of
the many activities with which he has been
associated.
Mr. Davis has a reputation for getting things
done, regardless of difficulties. His constructive abilities have carried him far, his contributions to the electrical art have greatly aided in
the maintenance of the engineering supremacy
which is the Westinghouse ideal, and he is recognized, with particular emphasis, as one of those
to whom is due the development of methods for
the quantity production of first-grade electrical
apparatus.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 25, 1922

THE R. 0. T. C. INSPECTION
The Reserve Officers' Training Corps Unit of this University
is one of which the students have every right to feel proud. Since its
organization at Hopkins the unit has ever maintained a high standard
and has established a most enviable record.
Under the leadership of Major Enoch B. Garey the corps has
grown in leaps and bounds, both in strength and in popularity. Due
to the efforts of this progressive officer and the members of his staff,
the organization has greatly expanded and is now fully equipped
to give a thorough schooling in the military.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 25, 1922
TENNIS TEAM TO MEET LOYOLA

On Wednesday, April 26, the
tennis team, under the leadership
of Captain Duffy, will meet the
Loyola racqueters on the Homewood courts. The visitors have just
returned from a trip through Virginia, where they faced some of the
strongest country club teams in the
state. They have also tackled a
number of college teams and have
made a very creditable showing.
The team will be made up of
Kerr
and
Barrett,
Menton,
Sweeney, who for several years
held the Junior State Championship and played on the Baltimore
Country Club tennis team last season. They will be met by a team
picked from the following list of
Hopkins men: Rowland, Wells,
Hofmeister, Bloom. Jacobsen and
Duffy.
On April 29 Hopkins will meet
Drexel, and on the third of May
Catholic University will come here
for a match, followed by one with
Gettysburg, on the fifth,- A return
match will be staged at "Evergreen" on May 17 with Loyola.
The tournament has .been progressing slowly, owing to the intervention of the holidays. Captain
Duffy urges all the participants to
Play off their first two rounds by
the end of next week.
It is with great pleasure that the
followers of the tennis ball observe
the improvements which are being
made on the courts. Wire netting
has been placed on the backstops
and the steam roller has done much
to put the courts in good condition.

Mr. E. Ault, a member of the
class of 1920, now engaged in graduate engineering work at Cornell
University, delivered an address
on "The Graduate in the Engineering Field," at the last meeting of
the Hopkins branch of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
Mr. Ault stated that there are
a number of things that the young
mechanical engineer must consider
before taking a job. First, be must
determine if he has adequate training to do the necessary work. Then,
he must take note of how much
experience and knowledge he will
gain. This is, perhaps, the most
important consideration. "Indeed,
some engineers," he said, "change
jobs every three months for the
first five or six years after leaving
college, in order to gain practical
experience."
Another thing to decide, according to Mr. Ault, is whether one desires to stay at home or whether
one is willing to travel. Of course,
everyone likes to stay at home with
his friends and family. There are
a number of disadvantages, however, in staying at home, for in this

To further the interests of tilt.
University Rifle Team, Dr. Abercrombie has offered a cup which
will be given as a trophy for the
best shot in the University. The
competition will be open to any undergraduate in good standing, and
the firing will be done on the R. 0.
T. C. range. Any student desiring
to enter the contest must apply to
the Military Office before May 1.
The winner of the match shall be
considered the best shot in the University, and his name will be engraved on the silver trophy cup.
This rifle match will be an annual
affair and will be the culmination
of the Spring activities of the Rifle
Team.

Those who have given their lives and their
hearts to the service of the electrical art have
early learned that success with larger things is
assembled out of devoted care to the lesser details. Indeed, they will go further, and demonstrate that the little achievements of today are
the fundamentals that become the big things of
tomorrow. Just as Willie Hoppe, the great
billiardist, will tell you that there is no such
thing as an easy shot in billiards, so electrical
specialists have found that frequently the seemingly big conceptions have depended on the perfection of details that those unfamiliar with
electrical history would often mistakenly regard
as unimportant.
Thus the growth of Westinghouse, and of the
great industry of which it is a part, has been
compounded of many ingredients; of vision that
saw present needs and future requirements, of
engineering genius that could bring forth practicable designs to fill them, of courage that never
failed to try once more, of enthusiasm, and integrity, and faithfulness to the little and the
little-known jobs as well as to those that were
bigger and more pretentious. Westinghouse has
always had a need, and a welcome, for men who
could supply such qualities.

It is the daily expression of qualities like these
that earns a man the regard, as well as the respect, of those who work with him.
Perhaps the foregoing may suggest some of the
causes that lie behind the success, and this appreciation, of Harry Phillips Davis, Vice President in executive charge of all Westinghouse
production and engineering activities. During
the thirty-odd years of his service he has contributed consistently to electrical progress, not
only by his work on arc lights and meters and
transmission apparatus, but by his effective and
loyal attention to the detailed requirements of
the many activities with which he has been
associated.
Mr. Davis has a reputation for getting things
done, regardless of difficulties. His constructive abilities have carried him far, his contributions to the electrical art have greatly aided in
the maintenance of the engineering supremacy
which is the Westinghouse ideal, and he is recognized, with particular emphasis, as one of those
to whom is due the development of methods for
the quantity production of first-grade electrical
apparatus.
